intro: Acer platanoides f. acuminatum, commonly known as the pointed-leaf Norway maple, is a cultivar of the Norway maple. It is characterized by its elongated, acuminate leaf lobes, which give it a distinctive appearance compared to the typical Norway maple. The plant is a deciduous tree or shrub, native to the temperate regions of Europe. It typically grows to a height of 6–12 meters and features a broad, rounded crown. The leaves are dark green in summer and turn yellow in the fall, adding seasonal interest to the landscape.
